headline: Fed Lets Rates Stand, Fearing Harm to Asia
content:
The Federal Reserve declined once again today to increase short-term interest rates, apparently determining that the threat of inflation remained remote and that the latest phase of the worsening Asian economic crisis might be exacerbated by any rate rise now in the United States.Several weeks ago, there were hints that the Federal Reserve might be leaning toward increasing interest rates sometime soon. But a number of recent indicators, including continued low inflation and the announcement this morning of a modest decline in the starts of new housing, have lessened immediate fears of an overheating of the economy, market analysts said.The decision to leave rates unchanged, at least for now, was hardly a surprise on Wall Street, where many leading economists had predicted that the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee, which meets regularly to review interest-rate policy, would again sit on its hands. The markets yawned in response: The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day up 3.74 points, at 9,054.65, after having risen 62 points earlier in the day.While no one knows for sure what motivated the Federal Reserve's decision, its policy makers had reason to worry that an increase now would only worsen problems in Asia. In recent weeks, there have been signs of renewed economic trouble in Thailand and South Korea, and the images of Jakarta in flames last week rekindled fear of a contagion effect that would discourage further investment in Asia.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
A rate rise in the United States would likely have accelerated such a development, as investors moved to take advantage of higher returns in this country on short-term notes and bills. Continue reading the main story

headline: NEWS SUMMARY
content:
INTERNATIONAL  A3-13Indonesia Leader's Words Spur Crackdown in CapitalHard-line military leaders clamped down on the capital of Indonesia in an effort to choke off plans for a huge demonstration hours after President Suharto rejected calls to step down, saying instead that he would hold elections some time in the future. Soldiers blocked key squares and intersections. Barricades also isolated the Parliament building, where thousands of protesting students had camped overnight. A1The student protesters are treating the Suharto Government with undisguised contempt. Hundreds of students barged into the main chamber of the House of Representatives, filling up the seats and galleries and conducting a sort of spontaneous shadow government. A10The Clinton Administration has been giving crucial financial support to some of the most important Indonesian opposition groups, hoping to promote a transition to a democratic society, while also trying to shore up President Suharto. A11Irish Rock for PeaceBono, star of the Irish rock group U2, took to the stage in Belfast beneath a giant ''YES'' banner, bringing together two longtime adversaries -- John Hume, a Catholic, and David Trimble, a Protestant -- in the campaign for approval of a Northern Ireland peace agreement. They urged support for the agreement in a referendum on Friday. A3
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Demonstrations in ColumbiaA spate of political killings during the current presidential campaign drove thousands of Colombians to take part in nationwide demonstrations to demand an end to the violence. No arrests have been made in the attacks, which have left more than 50 people dead and dozens missing in the last month. A5 Continue reading the main story

headline: Fed Holds Rates Steady; Says Jobs Are a Concern
content:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 — The Federal Reserve retained its cautious outlook for the economy this afternoon, leaving short-term interest rates unchanged at 1 percent.Today's decision on interest rates came as no surprise, because Fed officials announced one month ago that they were prepared to keep the benchmark federal funds rate at its current low levels "for a considerable period."If there was an added nuance to today's decision by the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy, it was in its slightly more pessimistic tone about unemployment.In its statement accompanying today's decision, the committee noted that the labor market has been "weakening," and it reiterated past statements that the ability of businesses to raise prices remains "muted."
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
By contrast, the Fed said last month that labor market indicators were "mixed," a more neutral formulation. The new wording suggested that Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, is more worried than before that a continuation of today's relatively high unemployment rate — at 6.1 percent of the work force in August — could affect economic growth in the months ahead. Continue reading the main story

headline: THE MARKETS: BONDS; Prices Up on Signs of Sound Economy and Scant Price Pressure
content:
The prices of Treasury securities turned higher yesterday after a regional manufacturing report showed that the economy was remaining strong but without the price pressures that normally accompany such strength.The Federal Reserve's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee held its second monetary policy meeting of the year, and, as expected, concluded the meeting with no action on interest rates, and consequently little impact on the market.The 30-year bond rose 18/32, to 102 22/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.93 percent, from 5.98 percent on Monday.The Purchasing Management Association of Chicago's index of manufacturing activity rose unexpectedly for March, while the prices paid index dropped to 48.7 in March from 55.5 in February. It showed that fewer companies were reporting price increases and that employment eased in March.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Traders said the end of the quarter had a muting effect on activity yesterday, with much of the market's attention focused on the March employment report, which is scheduled to be released Friday.

headline: New Reports Show Little Reason Not to Be Optimistic on Economy
content:
Consumer confidence fell in March, but only slightly from a level that was the highest in 29 years, a business research group reported today.The group, the Conference Board, said its consumer confidence index fell to 134.3 points in March from 137.4 in February. Meanwhile, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its monthly index of manufacturing activity in the Chicago region, seen as a bellwether for the economy, unexpectedly rose to 59.5 points in March from 57.8 in February.Taken together, the numbers indicate that the economy remains on a roll, analysts said.''These numbers are still remarkable,'' said Kathleen Stephansen, economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities. ''The expectation is that income will continue and buying plans will hold up.''With inflation nearly absent, the Federal Reserve's policy makers, as expected, held interest rates steady today at a meeting of the Open Market Committee, which has not changed borrowing costs for more than a year.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Adding to the evidence that prices  are not threatening to accelerate, the Chicago purchasing managers reported that the index of prices paid by factories for materials fell to 48.7 in March from 55.5 in February, indicating that more companies reported price declines than increases.

headline: Fed Statement On Decision To Cut Rate
content:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, reduced its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point:The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 1 percent. In a related action, the Board of Governors approved a 25 basis point reduction in the discount rate, to 2 percent.The committee continues to believe that an accommodative stance of monetary policy, coupled with still robust underlying growth in productivity, is providing important ongoing support to economic activity. Recent signs point to a firming in spending, markedly improved financial conditions, and labor and product markets that are stabilizing. The economy, nonetheless, has yet to exhibit sustainable growth. With inflationary expectations subdued, the committee judged that a slightly more expansive monetary policy would add further support for an economy which it expects to improve over time.The committee perceives that the upside and downside risks to the attainment of sustainable growth for the next few quarters are roughly equal. In contrast, the probability, though minor, of an unwelcome substantial fall in inflation exceeds that of a pickup in inflation from its already low level. On balance, the committee believes that the latter concern is likely to predominate for the foreseeable future.Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were Alan Greenspan, chairman; Ben S. Bernanke; Susan S. Bies; J. Alfred Broaddus Jr.; Roger W. Ferguson Jr.; Edward M. Gramlich; Jack Guynn; Donald L. Kohn; Michael H. Moskow; Mark W. Olson; and Jamie B. Stewart Jr.Voting against the action was Robert T. Parry. President Parry preferred a 50 basis point reduction in the target for the federal funds rate.In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved the requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, St. Louis, Kansas City and San Francisco.

headline: President Leads the Roundup for Votes to Add Drug Benefits to Medicare
content:
With President Bush acting as lobbyist in chief, House Republican leaders worked feverishly today to allay conservative qualms and round up the votes needed to pass a bill to add drug benefits to Medicare.On the other side of the Capitol, the Senate worked methodically through amendments and turned back Democratic proposals to expand benefits under the legislation, which is officially estimated to cost $400 billion over 10 years.Sponsors of the Senate bill announced tonight that they had reached a bipartisan agreement on how to spend $12 billion of that money for demonstrations to test two rival visions of Medicare, one that relies on competing private plans and the other on the traditional government program. The full Senate has not approved the accord, but after days of dispute, it appeared to remove one of the last obstacles to approval of the bill.''We will now have clear sailing to final passage,'' said Senator Max Baucus of Montana, principal Democratic sponsor of the bill.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Leaders of both houses said they expected votes on final passage on Thursday or Friday. Lawmakers would try to iron out significant differences between the House and Senate versions in a conference committee next month. Continue reading the main story

headline: Text of Fed’s Decision to Hold Rates Steady
content:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to keep its target for the federal funds rate at 5 ¼ percent.Economic growth appears to have been moderate during the first half of this year, despite the ongoing adjustment in the housing sector. The economy seems likely to continue to expand at a moderate pace over coming quarters.Readings on core inflation have improved modestly in recent months.However, a sustained moderation in inflation pressures has yet to be convincingly demonstrated. Moreover, the high level of resource utilization has the potential to sustain those pressures.In these circumstances, the committee’s predominant policy concern remains the risk that inflation will fail to moderate as expected. Future policy adjustments will depend on the evolution of the outlook for both inflation and economic growth, as implied by incoming information.Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were Ben S. Bernanke, chairman; Timothy F. Geithner, vice chairman; Thomas M. Hoenig; Donald L. Kohn; Randall S. Kroszner; Cathy E. Minehan; Frederic S. Mishkin; Michael H. Moskow; William Poole; and Kevin M. Warsh.

headline: Text of Fed Panel's Statement
content:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to leave interest rates unchanged:The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to keep its target for the federal funds rate unchanged at 1 3/4 percent.The information that has become available since the last meeting of the committee confirms that economic activity has been receiving considerable upward impetus from a marked swing in inventory investment. Nonetheless, the degree of the strengthening in final demand over coming quarters, an essential element in sustained economic expansion, is still uncertain.In these circumstances, although the stance of monetary policy is currently accommodative, the committee believes that, for the foreseeable future, against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are balanced with respect to the prospects for both goals.Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were: Alan Greenspan, chairman; William J. McDonough, vice chairman; Susan S. Bies; Roger W. Ferguson Jr.; Edward M. Gramlich; Jerry L. Jordan; Robert D. McTeer Jr.; Mark W. Olson; Anthony M. Santomero; and Gary H. Stern.Voting against the action: none.

headline: Fed Is Content Not to Raise Interest Rates
content:
With new data suggesting that inflation will remain under control, the Federal Reserve voted unanimously today to hold its benchmark interest rate unchanged, saying the durability of the economic recovery remained uncertain.On a day when the Labor Department reported a bigger-than-expected surge in the growth rate of productivity, the central bank reiterated that it was not in any rush to raise interest rates, despite a sharp upturn in economic growth in the first quarter. The productivity gain is evidence that companies may be able to restore their depressed profit margins without having to jack up prices.The decision left the federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks at a 40-year low, 1.75 percent, where it has been for nearly five months. Economists said the Fed would probably not seriously consider raising rates until August, especially if the unemployment rate continued to rise, as it has in recent months.On Wall Street, stock prices were little changed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 28.51, to 9,836.55. The Nasdaq composite index closed at 1,573.82, down 4.66.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
In a statement, the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee stressed that the 5.8 percent economic growth rate in the first quarter was largely a one-time boost from companies' beginning to rebuild their inventories as the recession ended. It is not yet clear, the committee said, that economic activity is picking up on a sufficiently broad basis to ensure that a healthy expansion will continue. Continue reading the main story

headline: THE MARKETS; Leaving Rates Alone, Fed Shifts to Neutral as Sense of Crises Eases
content:
The Federal Reserve voted today to hold interest rates steady, judging that three rate reductions in the fall had given the economy a big enough kick to keep it growing at a healthy pace into the new year.The central bank's decision to shift monetary policy into neutral is the latest sign that the sense of crisis felt by economic policy makers in the United States and worldwide over the summer is easing.Although analysts still expect the American economy to slow substantially in 1999, perhaps enough to require further rate cuts next year, the continuation of the nation's long expansion no longer appears to be in any immediate danger.Neither the impeachment of President Clinton nor the military attack on Iraq dented the confidence of investors on Wall Street or shoppers in the malls. Growth in the current quarter appears robust. Fears of a credit squeeze in the bond market have abated. And while manufacturers and farmers still suffer from exports lost as a result of the financial turmoil of the last year and a half, the latest trade figures suggested that the worst may be past, even for them.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
''When they reviewed all the factors -- the domestic economy, credit availability and the foreign situation -- it is noteworthy that the Fed concluded this time that those factors did not look as worrisome as they had looked,'' said Maury N. Harris, an economist at Paine Webber. ''It's significant that in such a short period of time the world improved enough that they didn't feel the need to ease any further.'' Continue reading the main story

headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasury Bonds and Notes Fall
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 May 18, 1988, Page 00016Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell by as much as a point in fairly light trading yesterday, as market participants reacted negatively to the implications of a report showing a big drop in the nation's merchandise trade deficit in March.The sharp $4.08 billion decline in the March deficit from February's $13.8 billion shortfall was far above market expectations, and in the minutes after the 8:30 A.M. release of the figures, bond prices rallied by more than a point.But once analysts had a chance to study the numbers, the early enthusiasm gave way to sober reassessment and a sharp selloff.Closer examination of the data showed that very rapid export growth was the primary reason behind the improvement. Moreover, imports, which economists would like to see decline, rose again in March, although at a far slower rate than exports expanded.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Traders and analysts viewed the data as further evidence that the economy was expanding at a rapid pace. Faster economic growth, in turn, raises the chances of higher inflation. Continue reading the main story

headline: Text of the Federal Reserve’s Statement
content:
Following is the text of the Federal Reserve’s statement on Wednesday announcing it was holding its base federal funds target rate at a record low between zero and 0.25 percent: Information received since the Federal Open Market Committee met in November suggests that economic activity has continued to pick up and that the deterioration in the labor market is abating. The housing sector has shown some signs of improvement over recent months. Household spending appears to be expanding at a moderate rate, though it remains constrained by a weak labor market, modest income growth, lower housing wealth and tight credit.Businesses are still cutting back on fixed investment, though at a slower pace, and remain reluctant to add to payrolls; they continue to make progress in bringing inventory stocks into better alignment with sales. Financial market conditions have become more supportive of economic growth.Although economic activity is likely to remain weak for a time, the committee anticipates that policy actions to stabilize financial markets and institutions, fiscal and monetary stimulus and market forces will contribute to a strengthening of economic growth and a gradual return to higher levels of resource utilization in a context of price stability.With substantial resource slack likely to continue to dampen cost pressures and with longer-term inflation expectations stable, the committee expects that inflation will remain subdued for some time.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
The committee will maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to  ¼ percent and continues to anticipate that economic conditions, including low rates of resource utilization, subdued inflation trends and stable inflation expectations, are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels of the federal funds rate for an extended period.

headline: Judge Rises to the Challenge in Tavern Trademark Case
content:
A federal judge who will decide whether the name Tavern on the Green belongs to New York City or the restaurant’s current operators rained a barrage of  Socratic questions on a succession of trademark lawyers  who  popped up in the legal equivalent of Whack-A-Mole on Wednesday. 
Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum of the Southern District of Manhattan reserved judgment on the name, which was bestowed on the property by the city in 1934 and trademarked in 1981 by its operator at the time, Warner LeRoy, whose family has lost the right to run the restaurant and has placed it in bankruptcy proceedings. But Judge Cedarbaum seemed to give equal measures of agita and hope to each side. 
While offering little indication of which side she favored, the judge gave every evidence that she would treat the case as a complex intellectual-property dispute that could be breaking new legal ground. “This is a very interesting case,” she said at one point, assuming a half-smile.
The ownership issue has been a flash point in Tavern’s bankruptcy case since the name — which has been appraised at $19 million — is potentially the restaurant’s most valuable asset.
Lawyers on both sides were circumspect after the hearing. The case “raises a lot of issues of concern to the court,” said Gerald E. Singleton, senior intellectual property lawyer for the New York City Law Department, “and this is far from a slam dunk for either side.”
Norman N. Kinel, lawyer for the committee of Tavern’s 452 unsecured creditors, who are owed $8 million, said that “from her spirited questioning, it is very clear that the judge is familiar with the arguments, and is giving the matter appropriate consideration.”
Other lawyers — there were 10 before the court and eight more attorneys and their assistants looking on — declined to comment. 
There was quiet drama in the incisive questions that enlivened the long play of argument centering on a legendary Manhattan building that began in 1872 as a sheepfold for a herd that chomped the grass in the adjoining field, now known as the Sheep Meadow.   
And both the city and the Tavern operators seemed to bear the brunt of the judge’s acute legal scrutiny. 
To the city, the judge stated flatly: “We have an incontestable trademark that you want to overcome as a matter of law.” She added: “Selecting a name doesn’t give you a trademark.” And of the incontestability, she said: “It is a heavy burden.” 
But to Tavern’s lawyers, Judge Cedarbaum commented about Mr. LeRoy’s use of the Tavern on the Green title that “he was given the name,” adding that “the city had always owned a building in Central Park that was called Tavern on the Green.”
When Mr. LeRoy submitted the trademark application in the 1970s the judge noted that he “didn’t disclose there had been a restaurant known as Tavern on the Green in the same place in Central Park for many years before.” Of making the sheepfold a restaurant, she said, “nobody questions that was the city’s idea.” 
The judge sent lawyers for both sides scurrying back to their offices to do homework, asking for more relevant prior cases that would shed light on the trademarking of a restaurant name describing a physical location, that is also a business providing services.  
The case has been bubbling in two separate federal courts. Only two weeks ago, on Dec. 1, Judge Cedarbaum ruled that she — and not a judge in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan — would decide the ownership issue. Under the federal judicial bureaucracy, bankruptcy court is subordinate when the district court asserts its jurisdiction. 
“Trademark law is something that this court regularly examines,” Judge Cedarbaum said earlier this month, referring to intellectual property disputes that frequently wind up in the Southern District. 
At his death in 2001 at the age of 65, Mr. LeRoy named his daughter Jennifer Oz LeRoy chief executive of Tavern; the family holds the license to the restaurant under the name Tavern on the Green Limited Partnership. The LeRoys and their managers have said the trademarked name would have value in other locations, and they already market a line of Tavern on the Green salad dressings and gift items.
In two weeks the LeRoys must surrender their jurisdiction over Tavern to a new operator. Dean J. Poll, who runs the Boathouse restaurant in Central Park, was awarded the city’s new 20-year license to run Tavern starting Jan. 1, but he hasn’t signed a contract with Tavern’s landlord, the Parks Department. And he has yet to come to an agreement with the Hotel Trades Council, which represents some 400 Tavern employees.
Mr. Poll’s lawyer, Barry B. LePatner, has said of the name, “the only prospective purchaser is Dean Poll — and he is not paying very much for it.”
In its most recent court papers the city argued that the Tavern name is specific to the Central Park location and “associated in the minds of consumers with a specific place.”
But in its latest legal filings before Judge Cedarbaum, Tavern’s official committee of unsecured creditors  termed the restaurant under pre-LeRoy ownership “Tavern-in-the-Red,” describing it as a “dingy little money-losing rustic pub” before the LeRoys made an “investment of many millions of dollars and a complete gut and rebuild,” transforming it to “a world-class, opulent restaurant.” 
Furthermore, the name Tavern on the Green “now stands for the excellent creation of Warner LeRoy,” David H. T. Kane, a trademark lawyer for Tavern, explained to the judge on Wednesday. Both sides agree that under the family’s tenure, it became one of the country’s most lucrative restaurants. 
But at the Wednesday hearing, the city also introduced last-minute evidence — from, yes, 1956 — in the form of press releases and questions and answers authored by Robert Moses, the city parks commissioner then, who originally oversaw the naming of the sheepfold as a restaurant called Tavern on the Green in 1934.
Mr. Moses was quoted as saying that Tavern “is patronized by hundreds of thousands every year,” adding that “in recent years the use of the Tavern on the Green in Central Park has increased so greatly that enlargement of the building” was necessary. 
Tavern’s lawyers challenged the admission of the materials, which were nevertheless discussed at length. The city’s lawyer, Mr. Singleton, was expected to use the documents as an indication that Tavern was a popular attraction long before Mr. LeRoy reinvented it in 1976, in an effort to undermine claims that Mr. LeRoy’s association amounted to value added for the restaurant. 
Potentially, the trademark could be a lucrative bankruptcy asset. Last year Gabe Fried, chief executive of another brand advisory firm hired by Tavern, Streambank LLC, said his company sold the trademark and brand of the bankrupt Circuit City electronics chain for $17.5 million, Mr. Fried said, and sold the trademark and logo of the bankrupt KB Toys chain for $2.1 million at auction. 
The Tavern on the Green name was appraised at $19 million by Marshall & Stevens, a valuation firm. But Mr. Fried said last week that “it is too early to speculate on the value” of the Tavern trademark.
Since the LeRoy family would lose the license to operate the restaurant in the new year, “the infrastructure that helped support the value of the name would not be there any more,” Mr. Fried said. Therefore, the name’s “liquidation value will be lower than the fair market value,” probably less than $19 million.
To Mr. Fried, “The bottom line is that it is hard to think of a restaurant name that has as broad national and international recognition as Tavern on the Green,” he said. 
To hedge its bets against a courtroom defeat, the city has already registered a substitute name with New York State: Tavern in the Park.
In court the LeRoys have submitted proof of the legality of the original trademark certificate of ownership, and proof that the family has successfully defended the trademark through the years; they have argued, too, that the city never challenged that trademark — even when it renewed the LeRoys’ operating license in 1985.
Furthermore, the LeRoys opened a fine-dining restaurant in Wellington, Fla., invoking the Tavern on the Green name in 2006. Though at the time the parks department sent a letter to the LeRoys requesting that the trademark be turned over to the city, the LeRoys claimed ownership and operated the restaurant until 2009 without further city objection. 
“After being silent and claiming absolutely no ownership interest in the Tavern Mark for virtually the entirety of three decades, the city now has mounted a full-court media and legal press centered on a baseless claim of trademark ownership,” the creditors have charged in court papers.
In its own court papers the city has termed the LeRoys “merely custodians and caretakers of the name,” adding that nothing in the license agreement “authorizes them to walk away with the name at the end of the license term.” 
Furthermore, the city has derided the notion, in the creditors’ arguments, that “some city employee actually had to don an apron and personally supervise food preparation at Tavern on the Green in order for the city to establish and claim trademark rights,” the city’s latest filings assert. 
The city has also excoriated the LeRoys for a “failure to produce” the early 1970s agreement whereby Warner LeRoy purchased the Tavern assets of Restaurant Associates, the previous operator, asking if the predecessor claimed to own — and sell – “the Tavern name to LeRoy?”
After an hour and a half of closely parsed disputation and pointed cut-and-thrust, Judge Cedarbaum asked for more information from the parties, saying, “I will do my best to expedite the matter.” Her decision is not expected before the end of the year.

headline: Text of Fed Statement on Rates
content:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to raise its benchmark interest rates a quarter-point:The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to raise its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 41/4 percent. Despite elevated energy prices and hurricane-related disruptions, the expansion in economic activity appears solid. Core inflation has stayed relatively low in recent months and longer-term inflation expectations remain contained. Nevertheless, possible increases in resource utilization as well as elevated energy prices have the potential to add to inflation pressures.The committee judges that some further measured policy firming is likely to be needed to keep the risks to the attainment of both sustainable economic growth and price stability roughly in balance.In any event, the committee will respond to changes in economic prospects as needed to foster these objectives.Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were: Alan Greenspan, chairman; Timothy F. Geithner, vice chairman; Susan S. Bies; Roger W. Ferguson Jr.; Richard W. Fisher; Donald L. Kohn; Michael H. Moskow; Mark W. Olson; Anthony M. Santomero; and Gary H. Stern.In a related action, the board of governors unanimously approved a 25-basis-point increase in the discount rate, to 51/4 percent. In taking this action, the board approved the requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, St. Louis, Minneapolis, Kansas City, Dallas and San Francisco.

headline: Fed Gives Mixed Sign on Rates
content:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 - After raising interest rates for the 13th time in a row on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve said that its work was not yet finished.As expected, the Fed raised the benchmark federal funds rate on overnight bank loans to 4.25 percent, from 4 percent. At the same time, it dampened the hopes of some on Wall Street that it was near the end of its campaign to control inflation by tightening its monetary policy."The committee judges that some further measured policy firming is likely to be needed," the policymaking Federal Open Market Committee said in a statement.In a clear effort to increase its flexibility in the months ahead, the Fed left its message even more ambiguous than usual.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
For the first time since it began raising rates in June 2004, it did not refer to its monetary policy as "accommodative," which has meant that interest rates were still lower than they should be to keep inflation low over the long run. Continue reading the main story

headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bonds Rally on Weak Output Data
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 November 14, 1990, Page 00013Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
The rally in the Government bond market continued yesterday, as traders pushed up prices of some Treasury securities as much as a point and long-term interest rates fell to their lowest levels since the Persian Gulf crisis began.The catalyst behind yesterday's move was a Federal Reserve report that industrial output had dropped eight-tenths of a percent in October, the first decline since April.The drop in the industrial production index was slightly more than had been expected, but economists and bond dealers said the depth of the decline was not as significant as its breadth.   'In a Downturn'"Sector after sector, product group after product group, showed declines," said Joseph Liro, a vice president and economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc. "The report shows that the economy is in a downturn with negative growth."
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Analysts said the report, which was released just before members of the Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee met in Washington, would provide further ammunition to those members of the committee who are arguing for an easing in monetary policy. Continue reading the main story

headline: Stocks Ease, With Dow Off by 4.95 Points
content:
November 14, 1990, Page 00006Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
Yesterday was a choppy one on Wall Street with stock prices dropping slightly. Trading was brisk and oil prices edged $1.25 a barrel higher, to $33.12. Program trading was heavy and small stocks picked up a bit.Nervous investors cashed in their chips after the Federal Reserve, which was widely expected to trim interest rates as soon as yesterday or today took no immediate action.By the end of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue- chip stocks gave up 4.95 points to close at 2,535.40. The American Stock Exchange's market value index and the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks edged ahead.Some analysts expect an upturn in the broad market before many days, largely because the Fed's widely heralded rate cut is still believed to be on the way -- particularly because of growing concern that the economy is faltering badly.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Activity dropped to 160.2 million shares, from 161.4 million on Tuesday, with 836 stocks rising and 731 falling. And 18 reached new highs while 39 fell to new lows. Continue reading the main story

headline: U.S. Output Fell 0.8% In October
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 November 14, 1990, Page 00001Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
The output of American factories, mines and utilities dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, prompting many analysts to declare that the economy as a whole has now conclusively slipped into recession.The decline, the first since April and the largest since January, was exceptionally widespread. And it intensified the belief that the Federal Reserve would move soon to cut interest rates again to arrest what could become a rapid economic contraction."The steep decline in industrial production in October demonstrates that the economy is now entering the free fall stage," said Gordon Richards of the National Association of Manufacturers. "The evidence of recession is now unambiguous."  A Definite ViewpointOn Wall Street, economists at the securities firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said today's figures, compiled by the Federal Reserve Board, "should remove the last vestiges of any doubt as to whether or not the U.S. economy is in a recession." The question now, they added, is its severity and duration.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Today's report, which covers sectors accounting for about a quarter of the economy, was the latest in a long litany of weak economic reports that show among other things a sharp slowdown in real estate construction and sales, a slump in retail purchases and a plunge in consumer confidence. Continue reading the main story

headline: Economic Scene;   Fed vs. Treasury On Dollar's Value
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 March 28, 1990, Page 00002Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
EARLIER this month, at a conference in Tokyo, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Manuel H. Johnson, said he was ''not uncomfortable with the current level of exchange rates.'' Hidden in that off-the-cuff comment may be a growing rift between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury Department over the dollar.Although Mr. Johnson's remarks seemed entirely consistent with those he had uttered in the past, this time the foreign exchange markets reacted by sending the dollar to three-year highs against the yen. Since then, the dollar has climbed even higher, although other factors, like the drop in the Tokyo stock market, have also had an effect.The most elementary reading of Mr. Johnson's remarks was that the Federal Reserve was content to hold interest rates firm and would refrain from intervening in the foreign exchange markets. But given the uncertainty in Japan's stock market, a non-interventionist policy would almost certainly drive the dollar higher against the yen, something the Treasury, which is concerned about exports, almost certainly does not want.Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in New York, found Mr. Johnson's comments so important that ''I devoted two issues of my newsletter to them.'' Normally, the Fed does not take a position on the value of the dollar. ''It does what it is told by the Treasury,'' Mr. Weinberg said. ''But this remark signals a potential shift in the way the Fed sees itself.''
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
When the Plaza Hotel accords were negotiated in 1985 to bring down the value of the dollar and stimulate exports, it was the Treasury that worked out the agreement while the Fed sat silent. ''But now it is very explicit that the Fed has a view,'' Mr. Weinberg said. Continue reading the main story

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   Treasury Issues Fall in Quiet Day
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 March 28, 1990, Page 00022Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers placed bids on $10 billion worth of new two-year notes - the only real activity of the day.''We thought the two-year would spark some interest, but even though the auction went well, it wasn't enough,'' said Joe Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc. ''We believe there is a lot of money on the sidelines, but at this juncture there is no reason for that money to come in.''At the auction, the notes were sold at an average yield of 8.59 percent, up from the 8.50 percent average yield at the last two-year note sale on Feb. 21, and the highest yield on a two-year note since the auction last May 24.As expected, the attractive yields generated strong demand from investors.Non-competitive bids for the notes, a good barometer of retail demand, amounted to $1.56 billion for the new notes. It was the largest non-competitive bid since the two-year auction held on April 26. $8 Billion Sale Today Today the Treasury is expected to sell $8 billion worth of new four-year notes. That auction will be followed tomorrow with the sale of $13 billion of 16-day cash management bills.

Late yesterday the four-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.57 percent. Continue reading the main story

headline: Text of the Federal Reserve Statement on Interest Rates
content:
Following is the text of the Federal Reserve’s statement on Wednesday announcing it was holding its base federal funds target rate at a record low between zero and 0.25 percent: Information received since the Federal Open Market Committee met in August suggests that economic activity has picked up following its severe downturn. Conditions in financial markets have improved further, and activity in the housing sector has increased. Household spending seems to be stabilizing, but remains constrained by ongoing job losses, sluggish income growth, lower housing wealth and tight credit. Businesses are still cutting back on fixed investment and staffing, though at a slower pace; they continue to make progress in bringing inventory stocks into better alignment with sales. Although economic activity is likely to remain weak for a time, the committee anticipates that policy actions to stabilize financial markets and institutions, fiscal and monetary stimulus, and market forces will support a strengthening of economic growth and a gradual return to higher levels of resource utilization in a context of price stability.With substantial resource slack likely to continue to dampen cost pressures and with longer-term inflation expectations stable, the committee expects that inflation will remain subdued for some time.In these circumstances, the Federal Reserve will continue to employ a wide range of tools to promote economic recovery and to preserve price stability. The committee will maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to   1/4 percent and continues to anticipate that economic conditions are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels of the federal funds rate for an extended period. To provide support to mortgage lending and housing markets, and to improve overall conditions in private credit markets, the Federal Reserve will purchase a total of $1.25 trillion of agency mortgage-backed securities and up to $200 billion of agency debt. The committee will gradually slow the pace of these purchases in order to promote a smooth transition in markets and anticipates that they will be executed by the end of the first quarter of 2010. As previously announced, the Federal Reserve’s purchases of $300 billion of Treasury securities will be completed by the end of October 2009. The committee will continue to evaluate the timing and overall amounts of its purchases of securities in light of the evolving economic outlook and conditions in financial markets. The Federal Reserve is monitoring the size and composition of its balance sheet and will make adjustments to its credit and liquidity programs as warranted.Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were: Ben S. Bernanke, chairman; William C. Dudley; Elizabeth A. Duke; Charles L. Evans; Donald L. Kohn; Jeffrey M. Lacker; Dennis P. Lockhart; Daniel K. Tarullo; Kevin M. Warsh; and Janet L. Yellen.

headline: Investors Retreat as Post-Fed Rally Quickly Fades
content:
Wall Street got an initial lift on Wednesday from the Federal Reserve’s assessment that an economic recovery was under way, but the glow faded fast, dragging stocks to their second day of losses this week.
The Dow Jones industrial average briefly crossed 9,900 points after the Fed released its statement at 2:15 p.m., but then a spree of selling pulled the market into the red, The New York Times’s Jack Healy reported. Financial firms led the way lower, and oil producers and industrial stocks slid as commodity prices dipped.
While investors found few surprises in the Fed’s words, the statement still offered some support for the prevailing economic outlook.
“The Fed statement didn’t really change anything,” Nick Kalivas, vice president of financial research at MF Globa, told The Timesl. “They went out of their way not to rock the boat.”
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 81.32 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 9,748.55. The broader Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index lost 10.79 points, or 1 percent, to end at 1,060.87, while the Nasdaq composite index slipped 14.88 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,131.42.
With no striking revelations from the Fed, investors homed in on nagging questions about whether stocks had become too expensive. The price-to-earnings ratio of the S.& P. 500, a broad measure of how stocks are priced compared with corporate profits, rose to its highest point in a year this week, according to Bloomberg News data.
In a regular Wall Street ritual, investors and analysts scoured a statement from the Fed as its Open Market Committee concluded a two-day meeting, seeking the central bank’s views on the prospects for inflation, interest rates and other aspects of the economy.
“Economic activity has picked up following its severe downturn,” the Fed wrote in its statement. “Conditions in financial markets have improved further, and activity in the housing sector has increased.”
As expected, the Fed left its key short-term interest rate untouched at a record low of close to zero, and it announced it would extend its program to buy more than $1 trillion in mortgage-backed securities to March 31.
Investors do not expect the Fed to lift its overnight federal funds rate until next year, given the huge challenges facing the economy as it tries to climb out of a deep recession. Unemployment is heading toward 10 percent, factories are still running at well under full capacity and credit markets are still fragile.
The prices of inflation-resistant investments fell on Wednesday as the Fed said that rapidly rising prices were not a threat, predicting that inflation would remain “subdued” for a while. Crude oil fell $2.79 a barrel, to $68.97, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, and gold and copper prices also slipped.
But investors grabbed up Treasury notes after the Fed released its statement, heartened by expectations of low inflation.
Yields on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note had been higher for much of the day after an auction of five-year notes drew lackluster response, but yields dropped after the Fed’s announcement as investors speculated that lengthening out the mortgage-purchase program would help to keep interest rates low.
“The mortgage market is such a huge driver of rates,” George Goncalves, head of fixed-income strategy at Cantor Fitzgerald, told The Times. “You have another large investor that hasn’t gone away.”
But Fed officials said the economy was continuing to improve, albeit slowly, leaving open the question of how and when the bank would begin to withdraw its emergency financing programs.
The Federal Reserve is monitoring the size and composition of its balance sheet and will make adjustments to its credit and liquidity programs as warranted.
The Treasury’s 10-year note rose 7/32 , to 101 23/32. The yield fell to 3.42 percent, from 3.44 percent on Tuesday.

headline: Fed Keeps Rates Steady but Paves Way for Rise
content:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 - The Federal Reserve kept its benchmark short-term interest rate at 1 percent on Tuesday, the lowest level in 45 years, but it laid the groundwork for a gradual tightening of monetary policy next year.In a significant shift by the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy, the Fed said the risk of "an unwelcome fall in inflation has diminished in recent months and now appears almost equal to that of a rise in inflation."That was a retreat from the Fed's language of the last several months, when it justified its policy of rock-bottom interest rates in large part on concern that the risks of declining prices, or deflation, were greater than those of inflation. At the same time, the Fed moved again to soothe investors by repeating its assertion that inflation remains low enough to allow a policy of cheap money "for a considerable period."Analysts and investors had been focused on that phrase in the run-up to Tuesday's meeting, with some predicting that the Fed would drop it and implicitly abandon its open-ended commitment to low rates.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
But Fed officials turned the tables, repeating the soothing phrase while at the same time alerting investors that they are no longer much worried about Japanese-style deflation. Continue reading the main story

headline: Fed Statement on Interest Rates
content:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged:The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to keep its target for the federal funds rate at 1 percent.The committee continues to believe that an accommodative stance of monetary policy, coupled with robust underlying growth in productivity, is providing important ongoing support to economic activity. The evidence accumulated over the intermeeting period confirms that output is expanding briskly, and the labor market appears to be improving modestly. Increases in core consumer prices are muted and expected to remain low.The committee perceives that the upside and downside risks to the attainment of sustainable growth for the next few quarters are roughly equal. The probability of an unwelcome fall in inflation has diminished in recent months and now appears almost equal to that of a rise in inflation. However, with inflation quite low and resource use slack, the committee believes that policy accommodation can be maintained for a considerable period.Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were: Alan Greenspan, chairman; Timothy F. Geithner, vice chairman; Ben S. Bernanke; Susan S. Bies; J. Alfred Broaddus Jr.; Roger W. Ferguson Jr.; Edward M. Gramlich; Jack Guynn; Donald L. Kohn; Michael H. Moskow; Mark W. Olson; and Robert T. Parry.

headline: The Dow Breaks Through 10,000 Before Falling Back
content:
The Dow Jones industrial average rose briefly above 10,000 yesterday, the first time the average has been above this psychologically important level in more than 18 months.But the Dow and the overall market retreated in the afternoon when Federal Reserve policy makers provided their first hint of the need to raise interest rates sometime next year, although they left their short-term interest rate benchmark unchanged. Treasury prices also fell as yields moved higher and the dollar slipped against the euro.The Dow has been flirting with 10,000 for several weeks, and after jumping 102.59 points on Monday to 9,965.27, the Dow looked poised for a break through.The 10,000 level was breached about nine minutes after trading opened, with the Dow rising to 10,003.05. But the Dow slipped back quickly. It made another run to 9,999.05 just after the Fed announced its decision at 2:15 p.m. Eastern time.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
At the close, the Dow was down 41.85 points, or 0.4 percent, to 9,923.42. The Nasdaq composite index, which briefly passed 2,000 in intraday trading last week, tumbled 40.53 points, or 2.1 percent, to 1,908.32. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 9.12 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,060.18. Continue reading the main story

And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 9.12 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,060.18. Continue reading the main story

headline: Stocks Gain Broadly; Dow Rises 47.58
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 February 11, 1988, Page 1Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
LEAD: Stock prices moved strongly higher across a broad front yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average jumping 47.58 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,962.04.Stock prices moved strongly higher across a broad front yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average jumping 47.58 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,962.04.For the Dow, made up of stocks of 30 of the nation's premier corporations, it was the best performance since a 76.42-point gain on Jan. 4.But yesterday's rally was not limited to blue chips: On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,219 stocks rose and only 354 fell.A Two-Day Rally
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
In the last two days the Dow has gained 66.32 points and has reversed its recent somnolent trend.''It's about time,'' said Henry M. Greenleaf Jr., president of HT Investors Inc., a Providence, R.I., money manager. ''Our portfolios were about to atrophy.'' Continue reading the main story

headline: GAUGE OF ECONOMY SHOWS THIRD DROP IN 5-MONTH PERIOD
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 November 2, 1988, Page 00001Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
The Government's chief gauge for predicting the economy fell one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the third decline in the latest five months, the Commerce Department said today.Although most economists had been expecting a small rise in the index of leading indicators, they focused today mainly on the sawtooth pattern that has developed in the index since late spring. That, they said, along with other figures, was evidence that the economy has clearly begun to slow.''Some of the momentum has been left behind,'' said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist for Nikko Securities Company International, a Wall Street firm. ''I think the index is forecasting some further sluggishness.'' Growth Rate of 2.2 PercentLast week the department said the economy had expanded at a rate of 2.2 percent in the third quarter, somewhat below the average growth of the gross national product for the first half of the year even after allowing for a substantial loss of output from this summer's drought.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Few experts, however, found in the recent data enough negative factors to predict that a recession will begin in the next several months. One saw only ''a flat spot,'' another ''a stutter'' in the rate of growth. Continue reading the main story

headline: Bond Prices Drop as Fed Raises Rate
content:
Treasury prices turned lower yesterday after the Federal Reserve fulfilled investors' expectations and raised short-term interest rates.The central bank's monetary policy arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, raised its target on the Federal funds rate to 5.50 percent, from 5.25 percent. The rate, the interest rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, has not been adjusted since January 1996, when the Fed cut it a quarter-point amid concern that the economy was headed for a recession. The committee did not, however, adjust the discount rate, which is the rate the Fed charges its member banks for overnight loans.While the rise in the funds rate had largely been expected, the hawkish tone of the Fed's announcement had not. ''This action was taken in light of persisting strength in demand,'' the Fed's statement said, ''which is progressively increasing the risk of inflationary imbalances developing in the economy.''The comments ''suggest the Fed will not stop tightening until the economy shows signs of slowing,'' Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, said.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Indeed, concerns over the Fed's next move weighed down prices late yesterday.The price of the 30-year bond ended down 18/32, to 95 25/32. The bond's yield -- a benchmark for consumer and corporate interest rates -- rose to 6.96 percent, from 6.92 percent on Monday. Continue reading the main story

headline: FEDERAL RESERVE LIFTS A KEY RATE; FIRST RISE SINCE '95
content:
The Federal Reserve voted today to raise interest rates for the first time in more than two years, firing a warning shot at an inflationary threat that remained hidden over the horizon.The central bank took one of the smallest steps it could, nudging up the more important of the two short-term rates it controls -- the Federal funds target rate for overnight loans between banks -- by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. In doing so, it was trying to keep the economy from growing so fast that it generates wage and price pressures strong enough to threaten the nation's six-year economic expansion.Because banks tie their benchmark loan rates to the Federal funds rate, today's action will ripple through the economy, probably curbing investment and consumption somewhat by increasing the rates charged for many business and personal loans and for credit cards.The move was applauded as tempered but appropriate by a number of Wall Street and academic economists, many of whom say the current combination of strong growth and low unemployment will ultimately lead to a resurgence of inflation unless action is taken to slow the economy. They said the Federal Reserve was likely to keep trying to fine-tune the economy by raising rates at least once or twice more this year.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
''What the Fed did today is about right,'' said Paul A. McCulley, an economist at UBS Securities.But with few signs that rising prices are actually infecting the economy, the move drew criticism from a significant minority of economists as well as from labor unions, business groups and politicians who say that economic statistics overstate the threats to steady growth and that such factors as global competition and fear of layoffs have permanently damped inflationary forces. Continue reading the main story

headline: Text of Statement by the Federal Reserve
content:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates 50 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point:The Federal Open Market Committee at its meeting today decided to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 50 basis points, to 5 percent. In a related action, the board of governors approved a 50- basis-point reduction in the discount rate, to 4 1/2 percent.Persistent pressures on profit margins are restraining investment spending and, through declines in equity wealth, consumption. The associated backup in inventories has induced a rapid response in manufacturing output and, with spending having firmed a bit since last year, inventory adjustment appears to be well under way.Although current developments do not appear to have materially diminished the prospects for long-term growth in productivity, excess productive capacity has emerged recently. The possibility that this excess could continue for some time and the potential for weakness in global economic conditions suggest substantial risks that demand and production could remain soft. In these circumstances, when the economic situation could be evolving rapidly, the Federal Reserve will need to monitor developments closely.The committee continues to believe that against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future.In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of all 12 reserve banks.

headline: Text of Decision by Monetary Committee
content:
Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to raise short-term interest rates:The Federal Open Market Committee today voted to raise its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 5.5 percent. In a related action, the board of governors approved a 25 basis point increase in the discount rate, to 5 percent.Although cost pressures appear generally contained, risks to sustainable growth persist. Despite tentative evidence of a slowing in certain interest-sensitive sectors of the economy and of accelerating productivity, the expansion of activity continues in excess of the economy's growth potential.As a consequence, the pool of available workers willing to take jobs has been drawn down further in recent months, a trend that must eventually be contained if inflationary imbalances are to remain in check and economic expansion continue.Today's increase in the federal funds rate, together with the policy actions in June and August and the firming of conditions more generally in U.S. financial markets over the course of the year, should markedly diminish the risk of inflation going forward. As a consequence, the directive the Federal Open Market Committee adopted is symmetrical with regard to the outlook for policy over the near term.In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, Cleveland, Richmond and Kansas City. The discount rate is the rate charged depository institutions when they borrow short-term adjustment credit from their district Federal Reserve Banks.

headline: SHORT-TERM RATES ARE RAISED BY FED A QUARTER-POINT
content:
The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point today, saying that the combination of strong growth and low unemployment had left the economy vulnerable to an outbreak of inflation.It was the third time this year that the central bank had raised rates to check the economy's momentum, and the move clearly signaled that the Fed's growing faith in technology's ability to improve business efficiency and temper inflationary pressures has its limits.In explaining its action, the Fed emphasized a concern that Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, has stressed repeatedly in recent months: that the nation is literally running out of workers and that, as it does so, wages and then prices will inevitably be pushed higher, endangering an economic expansion that is about to become the longest in the nation's history.The Fed said it was raising its federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks to 5.5 percent from 5.25 percent; the move followed two other quarter-point increases this year, in June and August. Today's increase took back the last of three quarter-point reductions  made last year in response to the global financial crisis and returned the rate to its level 14 months ago.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
The central bank also removed its formal stance toward higher rates, moving to a neutral one that analysts said all but ruled out a rate increase at the next monetary policy meeting, which is scheduled for Dec. 21. Continue reading the main story

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Rates May Rise, but This Bull Is Hanging On
content:
INTEREST rates may rise, the Federal Reserve may fret, but there's just no keeping a good bull market down.Voicing concerns that the economy is too darn hot and employment is way too tight, the Fed yesterday raised short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. Stock investors generally dislike interest rate increases because, in the broadest sense, they raise the cost of operating a business. Rising rates also make bonds more attractive than stocks as investments.So it was not too surprising that the Fed's rate increase rattled stocks after it was announced. A quick blip upward could not be sustained, and the Dow Jones industrials fell about 140 points on the news.Minutes later, stock traders got their bearings and roared with approval over the move. The white-hot Nasdaq composite index gained 73.51 points on the day, a 2.28 percent increase. The Dow Jones industrial average raced ahead 171.58 points, or 1.59 percent. At the end of the trading day, the Dow stood at 10,932.33, just 3.8 percent below its high reached last August.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
The investor euphoria after the Fed's action seemed to be based on two assumptions. Most compelling was the view that the Fed's move was the last rate increase for the foreseeable future. The next meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee takes place on Dec. 21, an unlikely occasion for anyone except Ebenezer Scrooge to raise rates. The meeting after that, in early February, is expected to feature economic statistics distorted by Year 2000 anomalies. As a result, many economists have concluded that the Fed will not move again on rates until next spring regardless of what the economic numbers show. Continue reading the main story

headline: Genentech Agrees to Settle Patent Dispute
content:
Genentech Inc., the nation's pioneering biotechnology company, has agreed to pay $200 million to settle its long-running patent battle with the University of California over genetically engineered human growth hormones, according to a person close to the negotiations.The agreement is scheduled to come before the University's Board of Regents' finance committee at a closed meeting tomorrow night and to be approved by the full board in an open session Friday.The settlement was reported in The Los Angeles Times. That would be the largest payment ever for patent infringement in the biotechnology sector, where it sometimes seems as if every breakthrough is accompanied by a trip to court to settle who owns it.''We are not going to comment until it is completely final,'' said Laura Leber, a spokeswoman for Genentech, which is based in South San Francisco, Calif. Several spokesmen at the university said they could not comment until Friday. Lawyers involved in the negotiations declined to comment or did not return calls.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Patent lawyers said a $200 million settlement might be among the five largest in any patent case, although such figures are often kept private and the actual value of an agreement can be complicated by cross-licensing when both parties are businesses. But analysts said Genentech could easily absorb the settlement. Continue reading the main story

headline: Text of the Fed Statement on Interest Rates
content:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to raise its benchmark interest rates a quarter-point:The committee believes that, even after this action, the stance of monetary policy remains accommodative and, coupled with robust underlying growth in productivity, is providing ongoing support to economic activity. Aggregate spending, despite high energy prices, appears to have strengthened since late winter, and labor market conditions continue to improve gradually. Core inflation has been relatively low in recent months and longer-term inflation expectations remain well contained, but pressures on inflation have stayed elevated.The committee perceives that with appropriate monetary policy action, the upside and downside risks to the attainment of both sustainable growth and price stability should be kept roughly equal. With underlying inflation expected to be contained, the committee believes that policy accommodation can be removed at a pace that is likely to be measured. Nonetheless, the committee will respond to changes in economic prospects as needed to fulfill its obligation to maintain price stability.Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were: Alan Greenspan, chairman; Timothy F. Geithner, vice chairman; Susan S. Bies; Roger W. Ferguson Jr.; Richard W. Fisher; Donald L. Kohn; Michael H. Moskow; Mark W. Olson; Anthony M. Santomero; and Gary H. Stern.In a related action, the board of governors unanimously approved a 25-basis-point increase in the discount rate to 4.50 percent. In taking this action, the board approved the requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, St. Louis, Minneapolis, Kansas City, Dallas, and San Francisco.

headline: Fed Fails To Move On Rates
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 July 7, 1994, Page 00001Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
The Federal Reserve ended a two-day strategy session on monetary policy today without announcing an increase in short-term interest rates or explaining its apparent inaction.Analysts took this to mean that the central bank, which had raised rates four times since early February, was satisfied with early signs that the economy is slowing enough to minimize the risk of resurgent inflation.It had been widely agreed that the Fed's assessment of the domestic economy would outweigh its interest in supporting the dollar in world currency markets, even though higher rates, by making the dollar more appealing, would tend to enhance foreign investment and minimize inflation from imports. Markets' ResponseThe financial markets responded fairly positively, though with no great enthusiasm, to the apparent outcome of the Fed meeting. The dollar rebounded from its morning declines, blue-chip stocks rallied and bond prices showed relatively little change.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
But while today's result came as no surprise, some analysts had speculated that the Fed might continue its practice since early February -- when it began its current series of rate increases -- of providing a brief rationale for its moves, or at least to make a clear declaration that it had decided to leave its stance unchanged. Continue reading the main story

headline: Dow Rises 22.02 as Most Other Indexes Fall
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 July 7, 1994, Page 00006Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
Stocks were mixed yesterday for the second consecutive session, with the main blue-chip indicator up and the broader market indexes down, but off the lows for the day.Mindful of the bond market and weakness of the dollar, many investors were still unsure about the possibility of another increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, and moved to the sidelines to await the release tomorrow of employment data for June.At the conclusion of its two-day meeting yesterday, the Fed's policymaking arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, left its monetary policy unchanged. The lack of a rise in interest rates was particularly good news for cyclical stocks and was a factor affecting the divergence of the Dow Jones industrial average from the broader market indexes.Monthly auto sales data released yesterday were about in line with expectations, and as a result the blue chips continued to bounce back. Nadaq Index Slips 2.59 Points
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was moderate, with 233.6 million shares traded, compared with 194.5 million shares on Tuesday. The number of issues declining yesterday narrowly outpaced advancers, 1,082 to 1,024. Continue reading the main story

headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasuries Slip as Fed Fails to Act
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 July 7, 1994, Page 00005Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday after the Federal Reserve took no action on interest rates, raising concern among some traders and investors that the Fed was not being aggressive enough in fighting inflation.The Fed's policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee, said in a statement that its two-day meeting ended at 12:35 P.M. "and there will be no further announcement."Bond prices fell on the news after rebounding to be almost unchanged from earlier losses. A stronger dollar and falling commodity prices helped bonds recover a bit late in the day be to almost unchanged. The dollar recovered to 99 Japanese yen, unchanged from yesterday. The dollar also recovered late in the day from a 14-month low against the German mark. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities, meantime, which is considered a leading indicator of inflation, dropped 1.42 points, to 225.31.The price of the 30-year bond fell 3/32 , to 8411/32 yesterday. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.59 percent, from 7.58 percent on Tuesday.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
The Fed's announcement "tells the market the Fed gave up a great opportunity to make a move that would be judged as pre-emptive," said Anthony Chan, a senior economist at Banc One Investment Advisers, a Columbus, Ohio, firm with $8 billion in bonds. Continue reading the main story

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS; Dollar Recovers as Traders Await Rate Action by Fed
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 July 7, 1994, Page 00017Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
The dollar recovered yesterday from an early selloff that had sent it to a 14-month low against the German mark, as traders waited to see whether the Federal Reserve would make any move to push up interest rates.The Fed's Federal Open Market Committee ended a two-day meeting without announcing any action on its monetary policy, providing an indication that it had apparently decided to make no immediate move to raise interest rates to support the dollar.Many economists have said the Fed's assessment of the American economy would outweigh its interest in supporting the dollar.But traders said the Fed did not seem to be ruling out raising interest rates at some future date. Several said the Fed might be waiting for the Government's report on June employment before it acts.  "People still think there might be an interest rate hike in the cards," said David Durst, a trader at Bear, Stearns & Company. "Just because the Fed didn't act today doesn't mean they can't announce a rate increase later this week."
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Higher rates could buoy the dollar by making dollar-denominated deposits more attractive.The dollar fell to 1.5658 marks in early New York trading yesterday, its lowest level since April 1993. It was quoted at 1.5785 marks late in the day, down from 1.5810 marks on Tuesday.

The dollar also fell to 97.84 Japanese yen before recovering to close unchanged at 99 yen.Many traders sold dollars early in the day after Germany's Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, said efforts to support the sagging currency were sure to fail. "Germany's position, that intervention against a market trend can't succeed, has been proven," Mr. Rexrodt told a German newspaper. Continue reading the main story

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   U.S. Issues Dip in Quiet Trading
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 May 16, 1990, Page 00018Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in quiet trading yesterday, as dealers took profits after the recent strong rally.The price slide began during overnight trading in Tokyo, where a rise in the value of the yen against the dollar led to a mild selloff. Later, announcements that industrial production fell by four-tenths of a percent in April and that car sales for the first 10 days of May were weak failed to stir any enthusiasm, even though they would be a disincentive for the Federal Reserve Board to raise interest rates.''The market feels a little tired, even though it continues to trade very well,'' one Government securities trader said. ''With the Fed on hold for another month at least, it looks to me like prices are at the high end of a very wide trading range that has been established over the last couple of weeks.''The Federal Reserve Board's policy-making Open Market Committee gathered yesterday in Washington, and as the trader suggested, analysts and market participants are virtually unanimous that the Fed will vote to leave monetary policy unchanged.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
Pessimism Vanishes''It is premature to think that the Fed is going to ease policy soon,'' said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago. ''But the deep pessimism that was so prevalent in the market a couple of weeks ago has been washed out.'' Continue reading the main story

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;   Prices of U.S. Securities Lower
content:
View page in TimesMachine
 August 22, 1990, Page 00015Buy Reprints The New York Times Archives
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower in thin, volatile trading yesterday, as dealers used movements in oil prices as their major indicator to buy or sell securities.A sharp run-up in oil prices early in the day sent out a clear sell signal, pushing bond prices down by more than a point. But oil later came down from its daily highs, and that helped erase most of the decline in bond prices.Comments from Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister, calling for a negotiated settlement to the crisis in the Persian Gulf also helped buttress prices, even though Mr. Aziz did not offer to withdraw Iraqi troops from Kuwait and restore its monarchy.Traders said that the drop in stock prices had little influence on activity in the credit markets. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 52.48 points, to 2,603.96.
Advertisement
Continue reading the main story
''We are not seeing the move into Treasury bills that a drop in stock prices caused in the past,'' one government bond trader said. Continue reading the main story

headline: Text of Fed Statement on Rate Decision
content:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to raise its benchmark interest rates a quarter point:The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to raise its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 11/2 percent.The committee believes that even after this action, the stance of monetary policy remains accommodative and, coupled with robust underlying growth in productivity, is providing ongoing support to economic activity. In recent months, output growth has moderated and the pace of improvement in labor market conditions has slowed. This softness likely owes importantly to the substantial rise in energy prices. The economy nevertheless appears poised to resume a stronger pace of expansion going forward. Inflation has been somewhat elevated this year, though a portion of the rise in prices seems to reflect transitory factors.The committee perceives the upside and downside risks to the attainment of both sustainable growth and price stability for the next few quarters are roughly equal. With underlying inflation still expected to be relatively low, the committee believes that policy accommodation can be removed at a pace that is likely to be measured. Nonetheless, the committee will respond to changes in economic prospects as needed to fulfill its obligation to maintain price stability.Voting for the F.O.M.C. monetary policy action were: Alan Greenspan, chairman; Timothy F. Geithner, vice chairman; Ben S. Bernanke; Susan S. Bies; Roger W. Ferguson Jr.; Edward M. Gramlich; Thomas M. Hoenig; Donald L. Kohn; Cathy E. Minehan; Mark W. Olson; Sandra Pianalto; and William Poole.In a related action, the board of governors unanimously approved a 25 basis point increase in the discount rate, to 21/2 percent. In taking this action, the board approved the requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, St. Louis, Minneapolis, Kansas City, Dallas and San Francisco.
